questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to 3 days of malodorous vaginal discharge and severe vulvar pruritus. The patient is sexually active and had a copper-containing intrauterine device placed for contraception last year. Pelvic examination shows a thin, frothy, and green vaginal discharge with marked vulvar and vaginal erythema. Vaginal discharge pH is 5.5. The intrauterine device strings are visualized and protrude through the cervical os. Microscopic examination of this patient's vaginal discharge will most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flagellated, motile organisms. 


This patient’s clinical features (malodorous, frothy, green discharge with vulvar erythema, elevated vaginal pH) are characteristic of Trichomonas vaginalis infection. On microscopy, T. vaginalis appears as pear-shaped, flagellated, motile protozoa. The infection is sexually transmitted and commonly associated with increased vaginal pH (>4.5). Presence of IUD can increase risk of vaginal infections. Wet mount preparation is the most rapid diagnostic tool, showing motile organisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clue cells: Seen in bacterial vaginosis due to Gardnerella vaginalis; appear as epithelial cells covered with bacteria giving a stippled appearance. Discharge is thin, gray-white, and has fishy odor (positive whiff test).

 

 

Option B. Filamentous, gram-positive bacilli: Refers to Actinomyces israelii, an opportunistic infection associated with IUD use, but it causes chronic pelvic infection with sulfur granules, not acute frothy discharge.

 

Option D. Pseudohyphae: Characteristic of Candida albicans seen in candidal vaginitis; discharge is thick, white, and curdy with severe itching but vaginal pH <4.5.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations will you undertake to establish the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), according to the CDC criteria?

1. Laparoscopy

2. MRI

3. Biopsy and histopathological examination

4. Blood tests for ESR and CRP
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4



According to CDC guidelines, PID can be diagnosed clinically, but confirmatory diagnosis requires additional supportive or definitive tests.

 

  • Laparoscopy is the gold standard for visualization of inflamed pelvic organs. 
  • MRI and biopsy with histopathology provide structural and tissue-level diagnosis. 
  • Blood tests like ESR and CRP support the inflammatory process but are nonspecific. Thus, all four modalities can be undertaken to establish PID diagnosis.

 

CDC criteria for PID:

questions.text:
Identify the correct kit for the clinical presentations:

 

  1. Painful ulcers upon palpation, with suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy on the right side
  2. Vaginal discharge in a CSW with cervical erosions 
  3. Painful, swollen, and tender inguinal lymph node in a truck driver
  4. Painless ulcer in the genital area with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy in CSW; past h/o treatment of a similar lesion resulted in fever, malaise, tachycardia and vomiting
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-White, 2-Grey, 3-Black, 4-White


Syndromic management kits are color-coded in India for STDs/RTIs. 

 

  • Painful ulcers with suppurative lymphadenopathy suggest chancroid (treated with White kit). 
  • Vaginal discharge with cervical erosions in CSW suggests bacterial vaginosis/trichomoniasis (treated with Grey kit). 
  • Painful, swollen inguinal lymph nodes in truck driver point toward lymphogranuloma venereum (treated with Black kit).
  • Painless ulcer with systemic Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction on treatment indicates syphilis (treated with White kit containing benzathine penicillin).

 

STI KITS:

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to a PHC with skin lesions with sensory loss. On examination, the dermatologist observes the following morphology. How would you treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)

 

 

The skin lesions with sensory loss in this patient are characteristic of leprosy. The treatment involves multidrug therapy (MDT) using the blister pack shown in option (a). This MDT pack generally contains rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine, which are standard first-line drugs recommended by WHO for leprosy. Early use of MDT halts disease progression, prevents disability, and reduces transmission. 

 

Dosage:

 

  • Rifampicin 600 mg (once monthly, supervised)
  • Clofazimine 300 mg (once monthly, supervised) + 50 mg daily (unsupervised)
  • Dapsone 100 mg daily (unsupervised)
  • The duration is for 12 months for MB leprosy  in adults

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. The image shows the standard WHO MDT (Multi-Drug Therapy) blister pack for paucibacillary leprosy. This blue pack is used to treat patients diagnosed with paucibacillary (PB) leprosy, where there are fewer skin lesions[<5] and no nerve involvement.

 

Dosage:

 

  • Rifampicin: 600 mg once monthly (supervised dose); 
  • Dapsone: 100 mg daily (unsupervised dose); 
  • Duration: 6 months (6 monthly blister packs) for PB leprosy in adults

 

Option C. This is the green WHO MDT (Multi-Drug Therapy) blister pack for paucibacillary (PB) leprosy, specifically formulated for children

 

Dosage:

 

  • Rifampicin:
    •  450 mg for children 10-14 years,
    •  300 mg for children under 10
    • Dapsone:
    •  50 mg daily for children 10-14 years, 
    •  25 mg for under 10 years. Alternate day dosing (50 mg) can be used for young children.
    • The duration is for 6 months for PB leprosy in Children

 

Option D. This is the Brown WHO MDT (Multi-Drug Therapy) blister pack for Multibacillary (MB) leprosy, specifically formulated for children

 

The WHO MDT (Multi-Drug Therapy) dose for multibacillary (MB) leprosy in children is generally weight-based and adjusted as follows:

 

  • Rifampicin:
    • Children 10-14 years: 450 mg once monthly (supervised),
    • Children under 10 years: 300 mg once monthly
  • Clofazimine:
    •  Children 10-14 years: 150 mg once monthly plus 50 mg daily (alternate day dosing for younger children), 
    • Children under 10 years: 100 mg once monthly plus 50 mg daily (usually alternate day)
  • Dapsone:
    • Children 10-14 years: 50 mg daily.
    • Children under 10 years: 25 mg daily or 50 mg on alternate days

 

The duration of treatment is 12 months for MB leprosy in children

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin malignancy and often occurs on sun-exposed areas like the face, particularly near the nose and medial canthus. The classical presentation is a slow-growing ulcer with raised, pearly rolled edges (“rodent ulcer”). It is locally invasive but rarely metastasizes. Risk factors include chronic sun exposure, fair skin, and genetic conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum. Early recognition and excision prevent extensive local tissue destruction. 

 

The histopathology BCC shows acanthotic epidermis with underlying basaloid malignant cells in nodular pattern with peripheral palisading and retraction artifact:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lentigo maligna melanoma: Occurs on sun-damaged skin in elderly patients, usually as a slowly enlarging pigmented macule on the face, not as an ulcerative lesion. Unlike BCC, it shows marked pigmentation and irregular borders.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a firm, indurated, ulcerated lesion with everted margins, often on lips, ears, or chronically inflamed/scarred areas. It has a higher metastatic potential compared to BCC.

 

Option D. Nevus: A benign lesion, usually pigmented, flat or raised, and stable in size. Malignant change is rare but can evolve into melanoma. Nevi do not present as ulcerative lesions near the nose.

questions.text: A male patient complained of bone and joint pain and was prescribed NSAIDs. After a few days, he returned with vesiculo-bullous lesions that subsequently healed, leaving a brownish discoloration on his face (particularly in the upper lip area), as shown in the image. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fixed drug eruption

 

The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of a Fixed drug eruption. Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common forms of drug induced exanthems.

 

A fixed drug eruption is a known adverse drug reaction characterized by recurrent skin eruptions at the same location upon re-exposure to a specific drug. The vesiculo-bullous lesions followed by brownish discoloration can be seen in fixed drug eruptions, making it the most likely diagnosis given the patient's history of NSAID use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the Plasmodium parasite, which is transmitted to humans via the bites of infected Anopheles mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: Fever (often cyclic), chills, sweating, headaches, muscle pains, fatigue, anemia, jaundice due to hemolysis, and enlargement of the spleen.
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: Malaria does not typically cause vesico-bullous lesions or discoloration of the face.

 

Option B. Dengue:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the dengue virus, which is transmitted through the bite of Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: High fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding (e.g., nose or gum bleed, or easy bruising).
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: While dengue can cause rashes, it does not usually result in vesico-bullous lesions or leave a persistent brownish discoloration on the skin.

 

Option C. Chikungunya fever:

 

A strong differential diagnosis is post chikungunya pigmentation (PCP) of the face seen on the nose & cheeks (Chik Sign) as shown in the below image.

 

 

Why it's not the likely diagnosis: However, this is not the answer because there is no antecedent history of fever, myalgia, or other symptoms suggestive of chikungunya. PCP often appears as the fever subsides and may persist for about three to six months. PCP mimics melasma & may be misdiagnosed If proper history is not taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

 

FDE is a drug eruption distinguished by its recurrence at the same sites on re‐challenge with the same drug, hence their site on the skin is fixed, it has a short latency and is benign in nature.

 

FDE typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.

 

  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply‐defined, round or oval erythematous and edematous plaque which evolves to become dusky, violaceous and occasionally vesicular or bullous.
  • Classically hyperpigmentation occurs after lesions heal. Most common cause:
    • NSAIDs - On Lips
    • Cotrimoxazole - On Genitals

 

Acute onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAID's are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 118 page no 118.11, 118.12

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition pages 141-142, 1633

questions.text: A 35 year old female patient presents with lesions involving the axillary, inframammary, and inguinal creases as shown below. No scales are noted on examination. Which of the following types could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inverse psoriasis

 

Inverse psoriasis (flexural psoriasis) occurs in intertriginous areas such as axillae, inframammary folds, and groin. Unlike classical psoriasis, the lesions are erythematous, shiny, and smooth without scales due to the moist environment of skin folds. It is often mistaken for fungal or bacterial infections. Diagnosis is clinical, and biopsy may confirm. Treatment includes topical corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, and avoiding friction/moisture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcal impetigo: Usually affects children; presents as superficial pustules that rupture to form golden-yellow crusts, commonly on face and extremities, not confined to intertriginous folds.

 

Option C. Acanthosis nigricans: Characterized by hyperpigmented, velvety thickening of skin in axilla, neck, and groin. It is not erythematous or inflammatory and is often associated with insulin resistance or malignancy.

 

Option D. Seborrheic psoriasis: A variant affecting scalp, face, and retroauricular areas with greasy scales. Intertriginous involvement is less common, and scaling is usually present, unlike the smooth lesions of inverse psoriasis.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermal Verrucous Nevus

 

The lesion shown in the image is a linear, raised, dark brown, rough-surfaced plaque. This is characteristic of an epidermal verrucous nevus (VEN), particularly in its "linear" variant:

 

  • Epidermal verrucous nevus typically presents as a warty, verrucous, or velvety plaque, often following Blaschko's lines (linear or spiral formations on the skin).
  • The lesion develops at birth or in early childhood, and its surface becomes more verrucous with age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital melanocytic nevus: Congenital melanocytic nevus might be large, dark, and hairy, but usually lacks the pronounced verrucous surface seen here.

 

Option C. Melanoacanthoma: Melanoacanthoma is a solitary, deeply pigmented papule or nodule, not typically linear or warty in appearance.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma: Malignant melanoma shows asymmetry, color variation, irregular borders, and often rapid changes; the described lesion does not fit classic melanoma feature

questions.text: A child was brought to a pediatrician with tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema. Immunofluorescence of the biopsy specimen is shown below. What is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dapsone 

 

Linear IgA bullous dermatosis is an autoimmune blistering disorder seen in children and adults. It is characterized by tense bullae, vesicles, and the classic “string of pearls” or annular arrangement of lesions. Direct immunofluorescence shows linear deposition of IgA at the dermoepidermal junction. Dapsone is the first-line therapy, as it rapidly controls blistering due to its anti-neutrophilic action. Corticosteroids may be added in refractory cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rituximab: An anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody used in refractory pemphigus vulgaris and other severe autoimmune blistering diseases, but not first-line for Linear IgA disease.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: A calcineurin inhibitor used in severe cases of psoriasis or refractory autoimmune bullous disorders. It is considered second-line in Linear IgA if dapsone fails.

 

Option D. Azathioprine: An immunosuppressive purine analog, mainly used as a steroid-sparing agent in pemphigus vulgaris. It is not the primary choice in Linear IgA disease.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with vaginal discharge. There is no foul smell or associated pruritis. On examination, there is white discharge and the cervix and vagina are normal. A pH is done which is 4 and a vaginal smear shows the following. What is the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Physiological discharge

 

Physiological vaginal discharge is common in reproductive-age women due to estrogenic stimulation. It is usually white or mucoid, non-foul smelling, and not associated with pruritus or inflammation. The vagina and cervix appear normal. Vaginal pH is in the normal acidic range (3.8–4.5), and smear shows only normal epithelial cells with lactobacilli. No pathogens or clue cells are present. This requires reassurance, not treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis: Discharge is thin, gray-white, foul-smelling, and pH >4.5. Microscopy shows clue cells and a positive “whiff test” with KOH.

 

Option B. Trichomonas vaginalis: Discharge is frothy, yellow-green, with foul odor and pruritus. Vaginal pH >4.5. Microscopy shows motile flagellated protozoa.

 

Option C. Candidiasis: Discharge is thick, curdy white, with severe vulval itching. Vaginal pH remains normal (≤4.5), but smear shows budding yeast or pseudohyphae, not just normal epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred choice for treatment for acne with no improvement after 6 months of therapy with combined oral & topical antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotretinoin 



In patients with severe, recalcitrant, or nodulocystic acne not responding to ≥6 months of systemic and topical antibiotics, oral isotretinoin is the drug of choice. Isotretinoin targets all pathogenic mechanisms of acne: decreases sebum production, normalizes follicular keratinization, reduces Cutibacterium acnes colonization, and exerts anti-inflammatory effects. It is teratogenic, so strict contraception and regular monitoring of liver function and lipids are required during therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids: Systemic steroids are not used for routine acne management; they may even worsen acne (steroid-induced acne). They are reserved for special cases like acne fulminans.

 

Option C. Letrozole: An aromatase inhibitor used for ovulation induction in infertility and certain cancers. It has no role in acne management.

 

Option D. cOCPs: Combined oral contraceptives can be effective in female patients with hormonal acne, but in antibiotic-resistant or severe acne, isotretinoin is the definitive next step.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 1-day history of skin rash. Two weeks ago, she had an episode of recurrent genital lesions, which began with small papules and subsequently became vesicular with ulceration, crusting, and eventual healing. On physical examination, she appears comfortable. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Skin findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythema multiforme

 

Erythema multiforme (EM) is an acute, immune-mediated condition often triggered by infections, most commonly Herpes simplex virus. It presents with target lesions (concentric rings with a central dusky zone), typically involving extremities and sometimes mucosa. Patients are usually stable and afebrile. EM is self-limiting, and management involves treating the underlying cause (e.g., suppressive antiviral therapy for HSV). This patient’s recent genital herpes followed by target lesions is a classic sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disseminated herpes simplex infection: Presents with systemic illness, fever, diffuse vesiculopustular lesions, and potential visceral involvement. This patient is stable, afebrile, and has target lesions, not diffuse vesicles.

 

Option C. Primary HIV infection: Manifests with flu-like illness, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular rash, not with target lesions linked to recent HSV reactivation.

 

Option D. Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS): A severe mucocutaneous reaction often triggered by drugs, with fever, systemic symptoms, and widespread epidermal necrosis. Unlike EM, SJS has extensive mucosal involvement and systemic toxicity.

questions.text: What type of connective tissue is found in the region indicated by the black arrow in the provided image? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dense irregular

 

In the provided image, the black arrow points to a region with a meshwork of collagen fibers. This pattern is characteristic of dense irregular connective tissue, which is identified by its densely packed collagen fibers that are arranged in an irregular, haphazard fashion. This type of connective tissue provides strength and support and allows the skin to resist multidirectional forces. It is typically found in areas that require strength and rigidity, such as the dermis of the skin, which is what is likely being shown in this histological slide.

 

Dermis (precisely Reticular dermis) is made up of dense irregular connective tissue.

 

Irregular connective tissue, is characterized by collagen fibers that are randomly oriented in multiple directions.

 

Irregular connective tissue is of three types: Loose, Dense & Adipose.

 

Dense connective tissue can be found in areas where unsheathed organs are protected and where there is significant mechanical stress.

 

  • This arrangement of fibers provides strength and elasticity in multiple directions, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Function: Provides structural integrity and support for the skin.

 

Dense connective tissue:

 

  • It typically exists in the reticular dermis.
  • Muscle and nerve sheaths made of the superficial connective tissue
  • Adventitia of large vessels
  • Capsules of various organs & glands (e.g.: testis sclera, periosteum, perichondrium)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dense regular connective tissue features collagen fibers that are parallel to each other, conferring tensile strength in one particular direction. It is typically found in tendons and ligaments, where the force is exerted in a single direction as shown in the image below.

 

 

This is not what we see in the image, where the fibers are not arranged in parallel.

 

Irregular and Regular connective tissue

 

 

Option C. Loose regular connective tissue is not a recognized classification.

 

Option D. Loose irregular connective tissue is also not a recognized classification. What is commonly known is loose connective tissue (also termed areolar connective tissue), which has a much looser fiber arrangement and a lot of ground substance, often found beneath epithelial layers, surrounding blood vessels, and nerves. It has a different appearance from what is indicated by the arrow in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image shows dense irregular connective tissue, which is characterized by a dense network of collagen fibers arranged in an irregular pattern, commonly found in the dermis of the skin, providing strength and the ability to resist multi-directional forces.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.34

Grays Anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice- 42nd edition- page no 40, 41

questions.text: A young patient presents with an oval, waxy white plaque on his right shoulder as shown below. He reports having a VZV lesion on the same site a few months ago. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotopic response



The isotopic response refers to the occurrence of a new, unrelated skin disorder at the site of a previously healed and unrelated dermatosis. A classic example is the development of conditions like lichen planus, psoriasis, or granuloma annulare at the site of healed herpes zoster lesions. The exact mechanism is unclear, but altered local immunity after viral damage is suspected. This fits the clinical history of a plaque at the site of past VZV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reverse-Koebner phenomenon: Refers to the disappearance of lesions of dermatoses (like psoriasis) after trauma, opposite of the Koebner phenomenon.

 

Option C. Isomorphic response (Koebner phenomenon): Appearance of same lesions of an existing dermatosis (e.g., psoriasis, lichen planus, vitiligo) at sites of trauma.

 

Option D. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon: Lesions appear at the site of trauma due to inoculation/spread of infectious agents (e.g., warts, molluscum contagiosum).

questions.text: A 35 year old woman develops the following rash 10 days after using a specific hair dye and bleaching agent. What is the hypersensitivity reaction involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type 4

 

Allergic contact dermatitis due to hair dye (commonly from paraphenylenediamine, PPD) is a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction. This is a delayed, T-cell–mediated immune response that appears 48–72 hours or even later after exposure to the allergen. The clinical presentation includes erythema, itching, vesicles, and eczematous rash at the site of contact. Patch testing helps in diagnosis, and treatment involves allergen avoidance and topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1: Immediate hypersensitivity mediated by IgE (e.g., anaphylaxis, urticaria, allergic rhinitis). Reactions occur within minutes to hours, not after 10 days.

 

Option B. Type 2: Antibody-mediated cytotoxic reaction (IgG/IgM) against cell-surface antigens, seen in conditions like autoimmune hemolytic anemia or Goodpasture’s syndrome. Not relevant here.

 

Option C. Type 3: Immune complex–mediated reaction, seen in serum sickness, SLE, or post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Presents with systemic vasculitic features, not localized dermatitis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Candidal intertrigo 



Candidal intertrigo is a superficial fungal infection caused by Candida albicans, occurring in warm, moist, occluded areas such as toe clefts, groin, axilla, and inframammary folds. It presents as erythematous, macerated plaques with satellite pustules. Risk factors include diabetes, obesity, and excessive sweating. Diagnosis is clinical and confirmed by KOH mount showing budding yeast with pseudohyphae. Treatment is with topical or systemic antifungals and keeping the area dry.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal paronychia: Involves the nail folds, presenting with painful swelling, erythema, and pus discharge around nails. It does not occur in toe clefts.

 

 

Option C. Diabetic foot ulcer: Chronic non-healing ulcer with necrotic tissue, often associated with neuropathy and ischemia. Unlike candidal intertrigo, it is deeper and not limited to superficial folds.

 

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): Caused by S. aureus exfoliative toxins, presenting with widespread erythema, tenderness, and superficial blistering with Nikolsky sign positive. It does not localize to interdigital clefts.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with such morphology of lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urticaria 



Annular lesions are ring-shaped with central clearing and raised margins, seen in several dermatoses such as tinea corporis, porokeratosis, and pityriasis rosea. Urticaria, however, typically presents as transient wheals—edematous, erythematous, itchy plaques that last <24 hours. These lesions are irregular or polycyclic rather than true annular rings. Thus, urticaria is least likely to show the morphology described.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea corporis: Dermatophyte infection causing well-demarcated annular lesions with central clearing and scaly advancing edges (“ringworm”).

 

 

Option B. Porokeratosis: Presents as annular plaques with an elevated keratotic ridge-like border, representing disordered keratinization.

 

 

Option C. Pityriasis rosea: Begins with a herald patch, often annular, followed by multiple oval annular lesions with collarette scaling along skin cleavage lines (“Christmas tree pattern”).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of skin lesions on his forehead. He says that he first noticed the lesions when he was rubbing his forehead because of their roughness. His medical problems include hypertension that is well controlled with chlorthalidone. He has worked as a farmer for 30 years. Physical examination shows the findings seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Actinic keratosis



Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion caused by chronic sun exposure, common in outdoor workers like farmers. It presents as rough, scaly, erythematous or skin-colored papules/plaques, often felt more easily than seen (“sandpaper-like texture”). These lesions carry a risk of progression to squamous cell carcinoma, so treatment includes cryotherapy, topical 5-fluorouracil, or photodynamic therapy. Early detection is essential to prevent malignant transformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a firm, indurated nodule or ulcer with everted edges. It is more invasive and destructive compared to the superficial scaly plaques of actinic keratosis.

 

Option C. Keratoacanthoma: Appears as a rapidly growing, dome-shaped nodule with a central keratin plug. Although it resembles SCC, it tends to regress spontaneously.

 

 

Option D. Seborrheic keratosis: Benign lesion in elderly patients, presenting as waxy, stuck-on, pigmented plaques with a “greasy” or verrucous surface, not rough/scaly like actinic keratosis.

questions.text: The presence of the following lesion can be due to which of the following virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HPV (Human Papillomavirus) 

 

Papules or verrucous growths on the fingers are most commonly common warts (verruca vulgaris) caused by HPV, especially types 2 and 4. These lesions are firm, rough-surfaced, and may be solitary or multiple. They result from HPV-induced hyperplasia of epidermal keratinocytes. Transmission occurs via direct contact, and treatment includes cryotherapy, salicylic acid, or electrocautery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coxsackie virus: Causes hand-foot-mouth disease with vesicles on hands, feet, and oral mucosa, not isolated finger papules.

 

 

Option C. MCV (Molluscum contagiosum virus): Produces dome-shaped, pearly papules with central umbilication, not rough hyperkeratotic warts.

 

 

Option D. HSV (Herpes simplex virus): Causes painful grouped vesicles on erythematous base (herpetic whitlow on fingers), not firm verrucous papules.

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of acute eczema?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intercellular edema 



The hallmark of acute eczema (eczematous dermatitis) is spongiosis, which means intercellular edema within the epidermis. The edema pushes keratinocytes apart but desmosomal attachments remain intact, giving a “spongy” appearance. This can progress to formation of intraepidermal vesicles clinically seen as oozing and crusted lesions.

 

 

Above histopathological image of dyshidrotic dermatitis, showing focal spongiotic change in the epidermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parakeratosis: Retention of nuclei in stratum corneum; seen in psoriasis and chronic dermatitis, not acute eczema.

 

Option B. Hyperkeratosis: Thickening of stratum corneum; occurs in chronic eczema or lichen simplex, not in acute lesions.

 

Option D. Intracellular edema (Ballooning degeneration): Seen in viral infections like herpes, not in eczema.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

  1. Methylisothiazolinone (MI) is used as a preservative in cosmetics to prevent microbial growth.
  2. Indeterminate leprosy has a higher rate of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.
  3. Salt and pepper pigmentation is associated with dermatomyositis. 
  4. Clofazimine may lead to copper pigmentation in the skin.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4

 

  • Statement 1: Correct. MI is a common preservative in personal care products and cosmetics to prevent bacterial and fungal contamination.
  • Statement 2: Correct. Indeterminate leprosy has a higher chance of spontaneous remission because of its unstable immunological state, whereas tuberculoid is a stable pole disease.
  • Statement 4: Correct. Clofazimine causes red-brown to black pigmentation, resembling copper-colored changes.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

  • Statement 3: Incorrect. Salt and pepper pigmentation (patchy depigmentation with retained pigmentation) is classically associated with systemic sclerosis, not dermatomyositis.

questions.text: Which causative agent is responsible for the 4-year-old boy's condition, characterized by painful mouth sores, a rash on the hands, and fever as shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxsackie A16

 

The given clinical scenario is likey suggestive of Hand Foot Mouth Disease as evident by the lesions shown in the image.Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease (HFMD) is a common viral infection of children under 10 years of age, especially in preschoolers. It presents with low-grade fever, painful vesicles in the oral cavity, and a characteristic rash on the palms, soles, and buttocks. The most common causative agent worldwide is Coxsackievirus A16, an enterovirus belonging to the Picornaviridae family. Another important causative virus is Enterovirus 71 (EV71), which is sometimes associated with severe complications like aseptic meningitis and encephalitis. The disease is self-limiting, usually resolving within 7–10 days, and is managed symptomatically with hydration and analgesics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coxsackie A24: 

 

  • This serotype of Coxsackievirus is primarily associated with Acute Hemorrhagic Conjunctivitis (AHC).
  • It presents with sudden onset of painful red eyes, subconjunctival hemorrhages, and photophobia.
  • It does not cause HFMD, making this option incorrect for the clinical scenario.

 

Option C. HHV-7: 

 

  • Human Herpesvirus-7 typically causes Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum) in young children.
  • It manifests as high fever for 3–5 days, followed by a sudden appearance of a pink maculopapular rash mainly on the trunk once the fever subsides.
  • Oral lesions and acral vesicles are absent, hence not fitting the presentation of HFMD.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: 

 

  • This virus causes Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease) in children.
  • It is classically characterized by the “slapped cheek” rash followed by a lacy reticular rash on the body.
  • It may also cause aplastic crises in patients with hemolytic anemia. Since painful oral ulcers and hand-foot lesions are absent, this is not the correct diagnosis.

choices.text: Koilocytosis of the superficial epidermal layers

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the OPD with a 4-day history of severe left-sided chest discomfort. The pain is constant and has a burning quality. Over the last day, the patient has developed a rash in the area of discomfort. He has not had similar symptoms before. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be found in the affected area?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ﻿﻿﻿Multinucleated cells with intranuclear inclusions

 

The clinical scenario is classic for Herpes Zoster (shingles) caused by reactivation of latent Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) in dorsal root ganglia. Patients first experience burning neuropathic pain in a dermatomal distribution, followed by the appearance of grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. On histopathology, VZV produces multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions (Cowdry type A bodies). A Tzanck smear from the base of the vesicle can reveal these cells. This cytopathic effect is shared with HSV, but the clinical presentation here strongly supports shingles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acantholysis and intercellular IgG deposits:

 

  • This describes pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by antibodies against desmoglein.
  • Histology shows loss of intercellular connections (acantholysis) and a “fish-net” pattern of IgG on immunofluorescence.
  • Not related to a dermatomal painful rash.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions: 

 

  • These are typical of poxyvirus infections, e.g., molluscum contagiosum, where large intracytoplasmic inclusions (Henderson–Patterson bodies) are seen.
  • Lesions appear as umbilicated papules, not painful grouped vesicles.

 

Option C. Koilocytosis of the superficial epidermal layers: 

 

  • Koilocytes are squamous epithelial cells with perinuclear halos and nuclear atypia seen in HPV infections (e.g., verruca vulgaris, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia).
  • HPV causes warts, not painful dermatomal vesicular eruptions.

choices.text: Can occur in association with diabetes
Associated with dermis thickening with mucin deposition

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Associated with Raynaud’s phenomenon 


Scleroderma diabeticorum is a rare cutaneous complication of long-standing diabetes, characterized by thickened, indurated skin over the upper back and neck. Histologically, it shows dermal thickening with increased collagen and mucin deposition. The skin may appear non-pitting and firm, but unlike systemic scleroderma, it does not involve Raynaud’s phenomenon, nailfold changes, or internal organ involvement. Management focuses on optimizing glycemic control and sometimes topical or systemic therapies to improve skin flexibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Can occur in association with diabetes: This condition is almost exclusively seen in patients with long-standing type 2 diabetes, often with poor glycemic control. The indurated skin changes are linked to chronic hyperglycemia and glycation of dermal proteins.

 

Option C. Associated with dermis thickening with mucin deposition: Histopathology demonstrates increased collagen bundles and mucin between collagen fibers, contributing to the firm, waxy texture of the skin. This is a key histologic hallmark of scleroderma diabeticorum.

 

Option D. Non-pitting edema is seen: The affected skin may appear swollen and firm, giving the appearance of non-pitting edema, which differentiates it from other diabetic skin changes like diabetic edema or cellulitis.

 

Note: Diabetes causes a range of skin changes due to poor circulation, nerve damage, and high blood sugar, including:

 

  • Dry, itchy skin; dark, thickened patches (acanthosis nigricans);
  • Red or brown spots (diabetic dermopathy);
  • Blisters (bullosis diabeticorum); stiff, 
  • Waxy skin on fingers (digital sclerosis); 
  • Increased susceptibility to bacterial and fungal infections

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the OPD for evaluation of red skin lesions on his chest. The lesions are not itchy or painful, and no other family members have skin lesions. Skin findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cherry hemangioma


The image shows small, bright red “cherry-like” papules on the chest, which are characteristic of cherry hemangiomas. These are benign capillary proliferations in the dermis, commonly seen in adults over 30. They are usually asymptomatic, non-tender, and sporadic, with no family history required. They are harmless and typically need no treatment unless for cosmetic reasons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cavernous hemangioma: Deep, bluish-red lesions that are often congenital and involve subcutaneous tissue, not small cherry-red papules.

 

Option C. Spider angioma: Central red papule with radiating thin vessels, blanchable on pressure, often associated with liver disease or hormonal changes.

 

Option D. Strawberry hemangioma: Infantile hemangiomas appearing in early childhood, rapidly proliferating initially, and involuting later; rare in adults.

questions.text: A 26 year old man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below, and adds that new lesions that are appearing at sites of injury. What is the underlying pathophysiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of Melanocytes

 

The image shows well-demarcated depigmented patches on both hands, and the patient reports new lesions at sites of injury (Koebner phenomenon). This is characteristic of vitiligo.

 

Underlying Pathophysiology

 

  • Vitiligo is caused by the loss of melanocytes from affected skin areas.
  • This results in complete depigmentation (milk-white patches).
  • The Koebner phenomenon (appearance of lesions at sites of trauma) is a classic clinical feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Failure of synthesis of melanin: This occurs in conditions like albinism, where melanocytes are present but are unable to produce melanin due to enzymatic defects (e.g., tyrosinase deficiency). The skin appears pale or hypopigmented, not with patchy depigmentation.

 

Option C. Loss of melanosomes: Melanosomes are the organelles that store and transport melanin within melanocytes and to keratinocytes. Disorders affecting melanosomes may cause mild pigment dilution but do not produce sharply demarcated depigmented patches as seen in vitiligo. The conditions associated with loss of Melanosomes are Hermansky–Pudlak Syndrome & Chediak–Higashi Syndrome.

 

Option D. Loss of keratinocytes: Keratinocytes are the main structural cells of the epidermis. Loss of keratinocytes leads to erosions, ulcerations, or other epidermal defects, not specifically to depigmented macules or patches like those seen in vitiligo.

questions.text: A 25 year old medical student preparing for NEET-PG presents with a reticular hyperpigmented lesion in the thigh as shown below. The following appearance is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exposure to hot temperature

 

The reticular hyperpigmented lesion on the thigh shown in the image is suggestive of Erythema ab igne.

 

  • Erythema ab igne is a skin condition caused by prolonged exposure to moderate heat or infrared radiation (heat exposure but not enough to burn).
  • It presents as a reticular (net-like) brownish hyperpigmentation typically on exposed sites such as thighs or shins after repeated heat exposure.
  • This lesion is associated with exposure to hot temperature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. An adverse reaction to drugs: Drug reactions typically present with diffuse rashes, urticaria, or fixed drug eruptions rather than reticular hyperpigmentation.

 

Option C. Exposure to cold temperature: This usually causes livedo reticularis, characterized by transient reddish-blue mottling primarily due to vascular changes, not hyperpigmentation.

 

 

Option D. Humidity: Humidity can contribute to conditions like intertrigo or fungal infections but is not associated with reticular hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: Which cells are not present in the layer marked as D?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Langerhans cells 

 

The area marked as D in the histology image corresponds to the stratum basale (basal layer) of the epidermis. Langerhans cells are absent from this layer and are predominantly found in the stratum spinosum above the basal layer. Thus, Langerhans cells are not present at D.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratinocytes: These are the most abundant cells in all layers of the epidermis, including the basal layer.

 

Option B. Merkel cells: These are specialized mechanoreceptor cells also present in the basal layer, particularly in areas of high tactile sensitivity.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: These pigment-producing cells are located in the basal layer and provide melanin to surrounding keratinocytes.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a 2-month history of a pruritic rash over the elbows and knees. The patient has been using skin emollients, but the lesions have not improved. He also has a prolonged history of episodic abdominal discomfort, flatulence, and voluminous greasy stools. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Skin examination shows a papulovesicular skin rash in groups with erosion and excoriations. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes

 

The clinical presentation with a pruritic papulovesicular rash over elbows and knees (dermatitis herpetiformis), along with gastrointestinal symptoms of abdominal discomfort, flatulence, and voluminous greasy stools, is characteristic of celiac disease.

 

The typical histological finding in celiac disease is increased intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs), which reflects an immune-mediated damage to the intestinal mucosa triggered by gluten.

 

Histology of Celiac disease shows Villous Atrophy and Crypt Hyperplasia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crypt abscesses in colonic mucosa: Crypt abscesses represent collections of neutrophils within colonic crypts and are hallmark histological features of ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease. They are not seen in celiac disease, which primarily affects the small intestine and is characterized by villous atrophy and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes.

 

Option B. IgG-mediated skin disruption: IgG-mediated blistering diseases such as pemphigus vulgaris involve autoantibodies against desmogleins leading to loss of keratinocyte adhesion. This differs from dermatitis herpetiformis, which is seen in celiac disease and involves IgA deposition at the dermal papillae causing pruritic vesicles.

 

Option D. Increased urinary porphyrins: Increased urinary porphyrins are seen in porphyrias, disorders of heme metabolism. Patients may have photosensitive rashes, but porphyrias do not typically present with the gastrointestinal symptoms or dermatitis herpetiformis rash described in this patient.

choices.text: Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex infection

questions.text: Topical steroids are most effective in: (AIIMS Nov 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eczematous dermatitis.

 

Topical steroids are the drug of choice in the treatment of eczematous dermatitis.

 

  • Topical steroids are anti-inflammatory medications that are highly effective in treating eczematous dermatitis, which is characterized by inflammation, redness, and itching of the skin.
  • They work by reducing inflammation and suppressing the immune response in the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermal atrophy: Dermal atrophy is actually a side effect of prolonged or inappropriate use of topical steroids, not a condition that is treated with them. It is thinning of the skin which can lead to transparency, easy bruising, and other skin changes as shown below.

 

 

Option C. Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex infection: Topical steroids are contraindicated in herpes simplex infections because they can exacerbate the condition by suppressing the local immune response, which is necessary to control viral infections.

 

 

Herpes labialis: Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex

 

Option D. Rosacea: Topical steroids may temporarily reduce inflammation associated with rosacea, but their use is generally avoided as they can lead to a worsening of the condition over time, particularly by exacerbating flushing and potentially leading to a condition known as steroid-induced rosacea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical steroids are effective in treating eczematous dermatitis due to their anti-inflammatory properties, but they should not be used for conditions like herpes simplex infections or rosacea, and can cause dermal atrophy if used inappropriately.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology, 9th edition page number 377

choices.text: Bacterial degradation of apocrine gland secretions
Proliferation of lipid-utilizing bacteria within pilosebaceous follicles

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the office due to several years of persistent facial blemishing that has failed to respond to over-the-counter treatment. Which of the following most likely contributed to the pathogenesis of this patient's skin condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proliferation of lipid-utilizing bacteria within pilosebaceous follicles

 

Persistent facial acne, as seen in this 22-year-old woman, not responding to OTC mostly arises chiefly due to the proliferation of lipid-utilizing bacteria within pilosebaceous follicles, primarily Cutibacterium acnes (formerly Propionibacterium acnes). This bacterium is a normal inhabitant of the skin but becomes pathogenic under conditions that favor its overgrowth.

C. acnes hydrolyzes triglycerides in sebum, generating free fatty acids that induce local inflammation and comedogenesis. It produces enzymes such as lipases, proteases, and hyaluronidases that degrade tissue and amplify inflammation

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Androgen-induced involution of sebaceous glands: This is incorrect because androgens stimulate, not involute, sebaceous glands. Increased androgen activity leads to sebaceous hypertrophy and excess sebum production, worsening acne.

 

Option B. Bacterial degradation of apocrine gland secretions: Apocrine glands are mostly associated with body odor and not involved in acne pathogenesis. Acne primarily involves sebaceous glands, not apocrine glands.

 

Option C. Estrogen-stimulated secretory function of sebaceous glands: Estrogen typically reduces sebaceous gland activity and sebum production, counteracting acne development. Therefore, estrogen stimulation is unlikely to cause acne.

questions.text: The farmer presents with an irregular mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury, as depicted in the image. Microscopic examination will reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sclerotic bodies


The clinical picture describes chromoblastomycosis, a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue seen in farmers and rural workers after traumatic implantation of dematiaceous (pigmented) fungi. It presents as a slowly enlarging warty, irregular mass on the foot or leg. Microscopy shows sclerotic bodies (also called Medlar bodies or copper-penny bodies), which are thick-walled, brown, round fungal cells seen in tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asteroid bodies: Seen in sporotrichosis, where yeast cells are surrounded by radiating eosinophilic material (“Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon”). Usually follows thorn-prick injuries.

 

Option C. Sulfur granules: Characteristic of actinomycosis, caused by Actinomyces israelii. These are yellow granules composed of bacterial filaments embedded in proteinaceous material, draining from sinuses.

 

Option D. Broom brush colonies: Seen in Aspergillus species on culture. Microscopically, the conidial heads resemble a broom or brush with septae and branching at right angle.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of a skin lesion. The lesion began as a pink papule on her right arm and has progressively enlarged over several weeks. It is not pruritic or painful and has not been associated with fever or other systemic symptoms. The patient returned from a trip to Shimla 5 weeks ago. During her travel, she stayed at a beachside resort and hiked in the rainforest. What is the following lesion associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bite from infected sand fly 


The patient’s history of travel, slowly progressive papule, and painless enlarging ulcer is classic for cutaneous leishmaniasis. The disease is caused by protozoa of the Leishmania genus and transmitted by the bite of infected female sand flies (Phlebotomus in the Old World, Lutzomyia in the New World). Lesions typically begin as erythematous papules and evolve into indurated ulcers with raised edges. The incubation period usually ranges from a few weeks to months. The condition is endemic in parts of India, the Middle East, Africa, and Latin America.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contact with infected person: This refers to some infections that  spread via direct skin-to-skin or mucosal contact, without the need for a vector. Examples include herpes simplex virus (grouped painful vesicles), molluscum contagiosum (pearly umbilicated papules), and scabies (burrows with nocturnal itching).

 

Option C. Handling of infected animal: This refers to zoonoses acquired through contact with animals or their products. Examples are anthrax (handling hides/wool), brucellosis (livestock, unpasteurized milk), tularemia (rabbits, rodents), and cat scratch disease (Bartonella henselae).

 

Option D. Swimming in contaminated water: Freshwater Swimming exposure may transmit schistosomiasis (snail-borne trematodes), leptospirosis (rat urine–contaminated water), or Naegleria fowleri, causing rapidly fatal primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. These typically cause systemic or CNS involvement rather than localized ulcers.

choices.text: The colony retains a white surface on 1% peptone agar medium
Clustered round microconidia on bright field microscopy
It can penetrate the hair shaft of the human hair in vitro

questions.text: A young boy presented the following appearance. Which of the following is not a characteristic of this organism causing the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The urease test is negative 


The disease here is caused by a dermatophyte (Trichophyton species), which characteristically shows positive urease activity. Dermatophytes, especially T. mentagrophytes, hydrolyze urea into ammonia, producing an alkaline reaction in the medium. This property is widely used in the laboratory to differentiate between T. mentagrophytes (urease positive) and T. rubrum (urease negative in early stages). Hence, the statement that “the urease test is negative” is false.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The colony retains a white surface on 1% peptone agar medium:  Dermatophyte colonies are classically fluffy, cottony, or powdery and white on the surface when grown on agar media like Sabouraud’s or peptone agar. Some species may develop pigmented undersides, such as red or yellow, but the white surface growth is a typical identifying feature seen in culture.

 

Option B. Clustered round microconidia on bright field microscopy: Microscopically, Trichophyton mentagrophytes produces numerous small, spherical to pyriform (pear-shaped) microconidia, often arranged in grape-like clusters along the hyphae. This contrasts with Trichophyton rubrum, which shows sparse, tear-drop microconidia instead. Such microscopic patterns are important for species identification in dermatophyte infections.

 

Option D. It can penetrate the hair shaft of the human hair in vitro: The hair perforation test is a diagnostic method used in the lab to differentiate dermatophytes. T. mentagrophytes is hair-perforation positive, showing its ability to bore into hair shafts, whereas T. rubrum is hair-perforation negative. This test highlights the organism’s keratinophilic nature and its ability to cause tinea capitis in vivo.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a facial lesion as shown in the image below. On examination, the lesions are painful & the edges are well demarcated & raised. Ear is also showing similar erythematous lesions. This infection is most likely to be caused by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Group A streptococcus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Group B streptococcus: Group B streptococcus (GBS) primarily causes infections in newborns and pregnant women but is an uncommon cause of skin infections in healthy adults. When it does cause skin and soft tissue infections, it is usually in immunocompromised patients or those with diabetes., although it rarely might present with classical erysipelas-like lesions.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus commonly causes skin infections such as boils, abscesses, and cellulitis but usually has indistinct borders and may produce pus. It is generally responsible for cellulitis.

 

Option D. Hemophilus influenzae type b: Hemophilus influenzae type b commonly causes respiratory tract infections, meningitis, and epiglottitis, especially in children.

questions.text: All of the following cytokines are raised in psoriasis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IL-4

 

IL-4 is a Th2 cytokine involved in allergic responses and humoral immunity. It is generally not elevated in psoriasis and often suppressed, differentiating psoriasis from Th2-dominant diseases like atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-2: IL-2 is a cytokine involved in T cell proliferation and is also elevated in psoriasis, contributing to the immune response. These cytokines are central to the disease pathogenesis and are therapeutic targets.

 

Option C. IL-23: Psoriasis is an immune-mediated chronic inflammatory skin disorder driven predominantly by the IL-23/IL-17 axis. In psoriasis, dendritic cells produce IL-23, which maintains and expands Th17 cells that secrete IL-17. 

 

Option D. IL-17: IL-17 acts on keratinocytes, stimulating them to proliferate excessively and produce chemokines, antimicrobial peptides, and pro-inflammatory cytokines that attract more immune cells to the skin, perpetuating inflammation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old, previously healthy woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of a raised pigmented skin lesion on her leg. The patient has had no itching or pain and cannot remember how long she has had the lesion. Biopsy of the lesion reveals nests of round, uniform cells at the basal portion of the epidermis that extend into the underlying dermis. The cells contain inconspicuous nucleoli and show no mitotic activity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Compound Nevus

 

The patient’s lesion demonstrates nests of uniform melanocytic cells at the dermoepidermal junction and extending into the dermis, with no atypia or mitotic activity. This histological pattern defines a compound nevus, a benign melanocytic lesion with components both at the epidermal-dermal junction and within the dermis. Compound nevi usually present as slightly raised, pigmented lesions clinically and are common benign nevi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical nevus: Presents with architectural disorder and cytologic atypia, including enlarged, irregular melanocytes and possible mitotic figures. It is considered a dysplastic lesion and may predispose to melanoma. Unlike compound nevus, it displays more irregular nests and cellular atypia.

 

Option C. Junctional nevus: Characterized by nests of melanocytes confined to the dermoepidermal junction without dermal invasion. Clinically, these are flat, pigmented macules and are typically darker than compound nevi due to the concentration of melanocytes at the junction.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma: Displays atypical melanocytes with nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, mitoses, and pagetoid spread (upward migration of melanocytes). Lesions often show continuous proliferation and invasion beyond the dermal-epidermal junction, unlike the uniformly bland cells in compound nevi.

choices.text: Alternating areas of orthokeratosis  and parakeratosis
Atypical lymphocytic cluster within the epidermis

questions.text: A 23-year-old male came with complaints of orange hue over the body with hyperkeratotic perifollicular erythematous papules associated with scaling, which started near the face and slowly progressed to involve the entire body. Islands of sparing noted over the body. Palmoplantar keratoderma noted. What is the most likely histological pattern seen in the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alternating areas of orthokeratosis and parakeratosis

 

The clinical scenario describes classic findings of pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP): orange-red scaling plaques with follicular hyperkeratosis, palmoplantar keratoderma, and "islands of sparing." The most distinctive histological pattern for PRP is alternating areas of orthokeratosis (normal keratin) and parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in stratum corneum) in both vertical and horizontal directions, sometimes described as a "checkerboard" pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atypical lymphocytic cluster within the epidermis: This is characteristic of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fungoides). It involves collections of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis (Pautrier microabscesses).

 

Option C. Lymphocytic infiltration around hair follicles: This finding is typical in conditions like lichen planopilaris or alopecia areata, which show folliculotropic lymphocytic infiltrates.

 

Option D. Dyskeratosis: Dyskeratosis refers to premature and abnormal keratinization of individual keratinocytes and is seen in diseases like Darier's disease or actinic keratosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the OPD with bilateral skin lesions over the posterior surface of the elbows. lesions are itchy at times; topical moisturizers have reduced the itching, but the lesions have remained. The patient has no chronic medical problems and takes no medications. Biopsy of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Psoriasis

 

The biopsy image and clinical scenario are classic for psoriasis. Histopathology shows hyperkeratosis (thickened stratum corneum=1), parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum=2), regular elongation of the rete ridges[=5], thinning of the suprapapillary plate[=3], and neutrophilic aggregates in the stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses=4). The most common sites for psoriasis include extensor surfaces such as the elbows.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Lichen planus: Characterized by a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermo-epidermal junction, hypergranulosis, and sawtooth acanthosis. It clinically presents with pruritic, purple, polygonal, flat-topped papules, often on flexural surfaces, not extensor surfaces.

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis: Shows subepidermal vesicles with neutrophilic microabscesses at the tips of dermal papillae, rather than parakeratosis and acanthosis. It is strongly associated with celiac disease and occurs mainly on extensor surfaces but with grouped vesicles and severe pruritus.

 

Option C. Lichen nitidus: Presents as small, shiny, flat-topped papules. Histology shows a "claw clutching a ball" appearance—a circumscribed infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes within the dermal papilla.

questions.text: Which of the following is a secondary skin lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

Shows Auspitz sign: multiple pinpoint bleeding observed on scraping the scales in psoriasis. A scale is an accumulation of loose, flaky, keratinized epidermal cells on the skin surface.

 

  • They are secondary because they develop from primary lesions like plaques, papules, or patches due to abnormal epidermal turnover or shedding.
  • Usually dry or greasy.
  • Often adherent, but can be scraped off easily.
  • White Silvery in nature in case of Psoriasis. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Shows grouped vesicles on an erythematous base:

 

  • This is typical of herpes simplex virus infection.
  • Type: Primary skin lesion (vesicle). Vesicles are fluid-filled, small lesions (<1 cm) and are directly caused by the disease process, not secondary changes.

 

Option C. Shows purpuric, necrotic lesions on the leg:

 

  • Likely purpura from vasculitis or meningococcemia.
  • Type: Primary lesion (petechiae/purpura) : These lesions are a direct manifestation of underlying vascular damage. They are not derived from another lesion.

 

Option D. Shows papules, pustules, and comedones:

 

  • This is acne vulgaris.
  • Type: primary skin lesion (papule/pustule). These lesions are primary acne lesions, incuding papules and pustules

choices.text: Lepromatous leprosy with positive Lepromin test
Tuberculoid leprosy with positive Lepromin test
Lepromatous leprosy with negative Lepromin test

questions.text: A patient presented with nodular lesions over the body, which are associated with slight anesthesia over the arm in the ulnar nerve distribution. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following options is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lepromatous leprosy with negative Lepromin test

 

The clinical findings (multiple nodular skin lesions and anesthesia in the ulnar distribution) and the histological image, which shows a clear, acellular zone beneath the epidermis (Grenz zone) and sheets of foamy macrophages filled with bacilli, are characteristic of lepromatous leprosy. Lepromatous leprosy patients have a poor cell-mediated immune response, resulting in numerous lesions and widespread disease. These patients demonstrate a negative Lepromin test due to a lack of specific delayed-type hypersensitivity to Mycobacterium leprae antigens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lepromatous leprosy with positive Lepromin test: Lepromatous leprosy is associated with a negative Lepromin test, not positive, due to deficient cellular immunity.

 

Option B. Tuberculoid leprosy with positive Lepromin test: Tuberculoid leprosy presents with few, well-defined hypopigmented lesions and strong cell-mediated immunity, leading to a positive Lepromin test. Histologically, granulomas are seen, not a Grenz zone.

 

Option D. ENL with negative Lepromin test: Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) is an immune complex-mediated complication in lepromatous leprosy and can occur during treatment, but the base disease remains lepromatous itself.

questions.text: A hair shaft with arthroconidia is seen in the image below. Identify the fungi associated with it?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microsporum

 

The image depicts a hair shaft surrounded by and containing arthroconidia—rectangular fungal spores—typical of an ectothrix infection (arthroconidia covering the outside of the hair shaft). The most common fungi that cause this pattern are Microsporum species, particularly Microsporum canis and Microsporum audouinii, which produce ectothrix hair invasion in tinea capitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichosporon: Trichosporon causes white piedra, presenting as white nodules along the hair shaft.

 

Option C. Candida: Candida species can rarely invade hair but most typically cause mucocutaneous and superficial skin infections, not ectothrix arthroconidia formation.

 

Option D. Epidermophyton: Epidermophyton species (notably E. floccosum) infect skin and nails but do not invade hair.

choices.text: Increased number of melanocytes are seen
It is associated with xeroderma pigmentosa
It is caused by increased melanin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased number of melanocytes are seen

 

The image shows classic freckles (ephelides), which are small, brown macules seen predominantly in photo-exposed areas, especially on fair skin. The pigmentation is due to increased melanin production in basal keratinocytes, not an increase in the number of melanocytes. Freckles can be associated with certain genetic conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum, and they commonly appear in sun-exposed areas. In freckles, the number of melanocytes remains normal; it is the melanin production that is increased. Increased number of Melanocytes are seen in Lentigenes but their function of melanin production remains normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seen in photoexposed areas: True; freckles are most commonly observed in sun-exposed regions such as the face, arms, and shoulders.

 

Option C. It is associated with xeroderma pigmentosa: True; freckles (and lentigines) are commonly seen in patients with xeroderma pigmentosum due to their extreme sun sensitivity.

 

Option D. It is caused by increased melanin: True; freckles result from increased melanin synthesis and transfer to nearby keratinocytes, not from increased melanocyte numbers.

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of fever, irritability, and rash for 3 days. The rash started around the mouth before spreading to the trunk and extremities. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F). Examination shows a diffuse erythematous rash with flaccid bullae on the neck, flexural creases, and buttocks. Gentle pressure across the trunk with a gloved finger creates a blister. Oropharyngeal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these skin findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxin-induced cleavage of desmoglein-1

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS), typically affecting infants. The skin findings (flaccid bullae, Nikolsky sign positive) are due to toxin-induced cleavage of desmoglein-1, a cadherin responsible for cell-to-cell adhesion in the superficial epidermis (stratum granulosum). Exfoliative toxins A and B produced by certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus act as serine proteases (epidermolytic toxins) that cleave desmoglein-1, causing loss of keratinocyte adhesion and resulting in epidermal splitting and blistering.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Bacterial production of erythrogenic toxin: Erythrogenic toxin is produced by Streptococcus pyogenes and causes scarlet fever characterized by diffuse erythematous rash and strawberry tongue, but it does not cause epidermal cleavage or blistering.

 

Option C. Bacterial invasion of the epidermis: In SSSS, S. aureus does not invade the skin directly; the epidermal damage is caused by circulating toxins that act remotely. Direct bacterial skin invasion occurs in bullous impetigo, not SSSS.

 

Option D. Autoantibody deposition in stratum spinosum: This is the mechanism in pemphigus vulgaris, where autoantibodies against desmoglein-3 disrupt cell adhesion, causing intraepidermal blisters. SSSS is toxin mediated, not autoimmune.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy with a known history of atopic dermatitis is brought to the emergency department with worsening facial rash and fever for 2 days. His parents state that he had an eczema flare recently for which they applied an over-the-counter steroid cream. Shortly after, he developed painful vesicles that spread rapidly over the cheeks. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex virus

 

This child with a background of atopic dermatitis who developed rapidly spreading, painful vesicles and fever after steroid use has eczema herpeticum. This is a severe form of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection overlaying compromised skin, often triggered in eczema by topical immunosuppressants. Key features include clustered vesicular lesions, rapid spread, systemic symptoms, and sometimes punched-out erosions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus: MRSA typically causes localized abscesses or impetiginization in atopic skin, presenting as yellowish crusts, not vesicles with rapid coalescence and pain.

 

Option C. Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus: MSSA leads to impetigo or cellulitis, also characterized by honey-colored crusts or erythema, not widespread vesiculobullous lesions as in eczema herpeticum.

 

Option D. Varicella zoster virus: VZV causes chickenpox with lesions in various stages (macule, papule, vesicle) and often involves the trunk and extremities, not limited facial vesicles with atopic history.

questions.text: The Fernandez reaction of lepromin test is read at:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48 hours 

 

The Fernandez reaction of the lepromin test is an early response characterized by erythema and induration at the injection site, reflecting a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction. It is typically read at 48 hours after intradermal injection of lepromin. This reaction indicates a cell-mediated immune response and is seen mainly in tuberculoid forms of leprosy.

 

Other Option:

 

Option D. 21 Days: The Mitsuda reaction is the late response read at 21 days and reflects granuloma formation and natural resistance to Mycobacterium leprae.

choices.text: Tzanck smear from the margins of blister
Tzanck smear from the floor of blister

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of oral ulcers and flaccid blisters. What is the first-line investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tzanck smear from the floor of blister 

 

The Tzanck smear from the floor of a fresh blister is the first-line investigation for blistering diseases like pemphigus vulgaris, which presents with recurrent oral ulcers and flaccid blisters. The smear demonstrates acantholytic (Tzanck) cells—detached keratinocytes resulting from loss of intercellular connections. Scraping the floor (erosion) rather than margin or roof of the blister yields the best cellular material for diagnosis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Direct immunofluorescence microscopy: This is the gold standard to confirm diagnosis of autoimmune blistering diseases by detecting IgG deposits but is done after cytology suggests pemphigus. It is not the first-line investigation due to time and resource requirements.

 

Option B. Indirect immunofluorescence microscopy [IIF]: Detects circulating autoantibodies in blistering diseases but is less sensitive than direct immunofluorescence. In fact, IIF is a powerful tool for screening and diagnosing a broad spectrum of systemic autoimmune, infectious, and neurological diseases by detecting specific autoantibodies or antigens in body fluids or tissues, rather than Dermatological disorders.

 

Option C. Tzanck smear from the margins of blister: The margin (intact skin surrounding blister) usually does not yield diagnostic cells. The floor is the preferred site for exfoliated acantholytic cells. Margin of blister specimen for HSV and VZV infections (herpes, chickenpox, shingles).

choices.text: Testosterone low, Dihydrotestosterone low, Estradiol normal
Testosterone high, Dihydrotestosterone low, Estradiol high
Testosterone high, Dihydrotestosterone low, Estradiol low
Testosterone high, Dihydrotestosterone high, Estradiol high

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the OPD to discuss hair loss. He has hair loss primarily around the temples, which began insidiously 3 years ago. Physical examination shows moderate thinning of hair at the anterior scalp, temporal region, and vertex. An oral medication is prescribed to treat the hair loss. After the initiation of therapy, which of the following changes would most likely occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Testosterone high, Dihydrotestosterone low, Estradiol high

 

The patient has androgenetic alopecia (male pattern baldness), which is driven by the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-α reductase. Oral finasteride, a 5-α reductase inhibitor, is commonly prescribed to reduce scalp DHT levels. With treatment, testosterone levels rise because less of it is converted, while DHT levels fall, reducing miniaturization of hair follicles. Some testosterone is also diverted to estradiol via aromatase activity, leading to a mild increase in estradiol levels. This biochemical profile explains why gynecomastia can occur as a side effect of finasteride therapy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is evaluated for a skin rash involving his hands, feet, and scalp for the last 2 weeks. The rash is mildly pruritic and has progressively worsened. The patient has a history of HIV and is not adherent with antiretroviral therapy. Skin examination shows erythematous patches with scales and crusting. Biopsy of the rash as shown below.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Topical permethrin

 

The biopsy image shows mites, eggs, and scybala (fecal pellets) within the stratum corneum, diagnostic of scabies. Immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV, may develop crusted (Norwegian) scabies—severe, widespread, highly contagious, with thick crusts containing large numbers of mites. The first-line treatment is topical permethrin, a scabicidal agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic acyclovir: Used to treat herpesvirus infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster, not parasitic infestations like scabies.

 

Option B. Systemic terbinafine: This antifungal is effective against dermatophyte infections (tinea) but not for mite infestations.

 

Option C. Topical glucocorticoid: Reduces inflammation in various skin disorders but would worsen scabies by suppressing local immunity and aiding mite proliferation.

questions.text:
Arrange the following corticosteroids in the order of increasing t1/2 (low to high).

 

1. Dexamethasone

2. Hydrocortisone

3. Betamethasone 

4. Prednisolone
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 4, 1, 3 

 

The order of increasing half-life from low to high is:
Hydrocortisone < Prednisolone < Dexamethasone < Betamethasone

 

The biological half-life (duration of glucocorticoid effect) of these corticosteroids generally increases in the order:

 

  • Hydrocortisone (short-acting): half-life approx 8-12 hours
  • Prednisolone (intermediate-acting): half-life approx 12-36 hours
  • Dexamethasone (long-acting): half-life approx 36-54 hours
  • Betamethasone (long-acting): half-life approx 36-54 hours

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of a healed forehead laceration. On examination, the scar is pink, firm, and mildly raised, without surrounding erythema or edema; it does not extend beyond the initial wound borders. The patient is reassured that the scar should flatten over the following months. The process by which this occurs relies mostly on enhanced cellular production of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metalloproteinases

 

The patient has a hypertrophic scar, which stays within the original wound boundaries and often remodels over time. Scar maturation and remodeling are primarily mediated by matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), which degrade excess collagen and extracellular matrix components. This breakdown allows realignment of collagen fibers and scar flattening. Balanced activity of MMPs and tissue inhibitors ensures normal healing, while excessive or deficient activity can result in abnormal scars. Over time, the raised scar should soften and flatten as collagen remodeling continues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasminogen activator: This enzyme converts plasminogen into plasmin, which plays a role in fibrinolysis and clot breakdown during the early wound healing phase. It places important role in debridement of fibrin clots, not Collagen Remodelling of Scar

 

Option C. Reactive oxygen species: ROS are produced by neutrophils and macrophages during the inflammatory phase of wound healing. They help kill pathogens and signal repair but excessive ROS cause tissue damage. They are not directly involved in collagen remodeling of scars.

 

Option D. Tumor necrosis factor-alpha: TNF-α is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that drives the initial immune response and promotes angiogenesis during early healing. Its role diminishes as healing progresses.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions is Nikolsky's sign positive seen?

 

  1. Pemphigus foliaceous
  2. SJS 
  3. Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  4. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4 

 

Nikolsky’s sign refers to epidermal shearing with gentle lateral pressure on the skin, indicating loss of adhesion between keratinocytes. It is seen in conditions with intraepidermal acantholysis or superficial epidermal splitting. Pemphigus foliaceous shows acantholysis in the upper epidermis, Stevens–Johnson syndrome involves widespread keratinocyte necrosis with epidermal detachment, and Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome shows exfoliation due to exotoxin-mediated cleavage of desmoglein-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 3-> Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita, however, is a subepidermal blistering disorder and typically has a negative Nikolsky’s sign.

 

Note: Pseudo-Nikolsky Sign (Sheklakov’s sign) - When pressure is applied at the margin of an existing blister, the blister extends into adjacent skin.

 

  • Not true epidermal shearing, but rather blister spread due to weak dermoepidermal junction.
  • Seen in:
    • Bullous pemphigoid
    • Epidermolysis bullosa

choices.text: Loss of function mutation in filaggrin
