questions.text: A 14-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents due to sores on her feet. Since she took her first steps 3 months ago, she has had blisters involving the soles of the feet, which subsequently break down and heal slowly. The patient had failure to thrive as an infant due to frequent oral ulcerations but otherwise has been healthy and has achieved normal developmental milestones. Examination shows small bullae at the soles with faint erythema and no scarring. Biopsy taken at the margin of a blister shows an intraepidermal cleavage plane. Which of the following most likely contributes to the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired keratin filament assembly

 

This child has epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS), a genetic blistering disorder characterized by recurrent trauma-induced bullae on pressure sites such as the soles. The disease is caused by mutations in keratin genes (KRT5 or KRT14), leading to defective keratin filament assembly in basal keratinocytes. As a result, the skin becomes fragile, and minor mechanical stress produces intraepidermal cleavage with blister formation. Oral mucosal involvement is common, explaining her history of recurrent mouth ulcers. Healing usually occurs without scarring, distinguishing EBS from deeper blistering disorders. Note the changes seen in Child with EBS:

 

 

(a, b) Pictures from childhood before the patient (EBS1) suffered an extensive burn injury. The patient continues to have occasional blisters and erosion on the soles and palms, particularly in areas of trauma. Old and new blisters and erosion with crusting are seen on the soles, heels and dorsum of toes. 

 

(c) Patient EBS3 had more severe blistering in childhood but continues to get occasional blisters and erosions on the soles and palms with extensive painful callosities. 

 

(d) The granddaughter had severe herpetiform blistering soon after birth and during early childhood. For other details see Table 1 and text.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoantibodies against tissue transglutaminase: This is the mechanism of dermatitis herpetiformis, a blistering disease strongly associated with celiac disease. It presents with grouped, pruritic vesicles on extensor surfaces rather than trauma-induced bullae on soles.

 

Option C. Loss of function mutation in filaggrin: Filaggrin mutations cause atopic dermatitis (eczema), leading to impaired skin barrier, xerosis, and increased risk of allergic sensitization. It does not cause trauma-induced intraepidermal blisters.

 

Option D. T-cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction: This mechanism underlies Stevens–Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis, in which cytotoxic T cells induce widespread keratinocyte apoptosis. These are acute, severe drug reactions, not chronic blistering disorders since infancy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with short, rough and thin hair. He has associated failure to thrive and developmental delay. A trichogram of his scalp hair is as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Menke's disease 

 

The trichogram shows a thin, twisted (pili torti) hair shaft, which is characteristic of Menkes disease. This X-linked recessive disorder is caused by impaired copper absorption and transport due to ATP7A gene mutations. Children with Menkes disease present with short, sparse, brittle, hypopigmented "kinky" hair, along with neurological deficits and failure to thrive. Hair microscopy reveals pili torti—hair shafts twisting 180° at irregular intervals—which is diagnostic for Menkes disease.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Kwashiorkor: Shows flag sign in hair (alternating bands of pigmented and depigmented hair) due to protein malnutrition but does not show pili torti.

 

Option B. Keshan's disease: Associated with selenium deficiency and cardiomyopathy, not hair shaft twisting or skin manifestations.

 

Option D. Trichothiodystrophy: Shows brittle hair with "tiger tail" banding on polarized light, but not pili torti as the dominant feature

questions.text: A wool farmer presents with a hemorrhagic lesion on his left index finger for 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ecthyma contagiosum 

 

The wool farmer has a hemorrhagic lesion on the finger described as ecthyma contagiosum (also known as = Orf), which is a zoonotic para-poxvirus infection commonly seen in people handling sheep and goats. The classic lesion is a painless, nodular or vesicular lesion that may ulcerate and scab, often on the hands or fingers at sites of contact. The occupational history and lesion appearance are characteristic for ecthyma contagiosum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthrax: Cutaneous anthrax starts as a painless papule that develops into a vesicle, then a black eschar; often surrounded by significant edema.

 

 

Option B. Erysipeloid: Caused by Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae, presents as a painful, violaceous, well-demarcated plaque, typically in people who handle fish or meat.

 

 

Option D. Ecthyma gangrenosum: Seen in immunocompromised patients with Pseudomonas sepsis; presents as necrotic ulcers with a central black eschar and surrounding erythema.

questions.text: Which of the following are included in malpighian layer of the epidermis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stratum spinosum and stratum basale

 

The Malpighian layer of the epidermis refers to the stratum basale (germinativum) and the stratum spinosum together. These layers are highly metabolically active, contain mitotically dividing keratinocytes, and are responsible for regeneration of the epidermis. They are rich in desmosomes, which provide mechanical strength and cohesion between keratinocytes. Melanocytes in the basal layer also transfer melanin granules to keratinocytes here, giving pigmentation. Since these layers are vital for proliferation and differentiation, they are considered the “germinative” portion of the epidermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stratum corneum and stratum granulosum: These are superficial non-proliferative layers. Stratum granulosum contains keratohyalin granules. The granulosum contributes mainly to barrier function and water resistance rather than cell proliferation. The stratum corneum is the outermost layer of the epidermis composed of dead, flattened, enucleated keratinocytes known as corneocytes. It serves as the main physical and chemical barrier, preventing water loss (trans-epidermal water loss) and protecting against pathogens, chemicals, and mechanical stress.

 

Option C. Stratum granulosum and stratum lucidum: The stratum lucidum is a thin, translucent layer of the epidermis found only in thick, hairless skin such as the palms and soles. It consists of densely packed, flattened keratinocytes that have lost their nuclei and organelles, appearing clear under the microscope. This layer provides an additional barrier to friction and shear forces, enhancing protection in high-pressure areas.

questions.text: SAPHO syndrome includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seborrhea

 

SAPHO syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by the acronym:

 

  • Synovitis (inflammation of joints)
  • Acne
  • Pustulosis (especially palmoplantar pustulosis)
  • Hyperostosis (excessive bone growth)
  • Osteitis (bone inflammation).

 

Seborrhea is not part of SAPHO syndrome

choices.text: Giant cells in a Tzanck preparation
Invasive cords of squamous cells with keratin pearls
Invasive clusters of spindle cells surrounded by palisaded basal cells

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office due to a slightly painful sore on his lip which has been enlarging for the last 3months. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. He works as a farmer and has no new sexual contacts. Vital signs are normal. Examination shows a 3x7-mm partially encrusted ulcer in the vermilion zone of the lower lip, surrounded by a 6x12-mm area of induration. There are no palpable submental or submandibular lymph nodes, and the remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Biopsy of this lesion will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invasive cords of squamous cells with keratin pearls

 

The chronic, enlarging, ulcerated lesion with induration on the lower lip is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lip, a malignancy commonly seen with chronic sun exposure. Farmers are particularly at risk. SCC of the lip typically appears as a nonhealing ulcer or crusted plaque, often indurated and sometimes tender.

 

Biopsy in SCC will show:

 

  • Invasive cords or nests of atypical squamous cells
  • Presence of keratin pearls (round collections of keratinized cells within tumor nests)
    This appearance is pathognomonic for well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giant cells in a Tzanck preparation: Giant cells observed in a Tzanck smear are multinucleated keratinocytes commonly seen in viral infections such as herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV). These giant cells arise due to virus-induced cytopathic effects causing cell fusion. This finding is diagnostic for herpes infections .

 

Option B. Granulomatous inflammation: Granulomatous inflammation is a distinct pattern of chronic inflammation characterized by the aggregation of macrophages transformed into epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells. It is typically seen in infectious diseases like tuberculosis, deep fungal infections, and certain autoimmune conditions such as sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. Invasive clusters of spindle cells surrounded by palisaded basal cells: This histopathological pattern is characteristic of basal cell carcinoma (BCC), a common skin cancer arising from basal keratinocytes. BCC shows nests of basaloid cells with peripheral palisading nuclei and stromal retraction. It generally presents as pearly papules, commonly seen over face.

questions.text: A 42-year-old mancomes to the office due to an itchy rash. The rash began 3 months ago during the summer since then has enlarged and spread across his back, chest, and abdomen. The patient has attempted treatment with topical emollients and over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream without relief. Examination reveals scaly, annular plaques, as shown in the exhibit. In addition to appropriate measures for treatment of the rash, which of the following should be done at this time?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV screening test

 

The patient’s presentation of widespread scaly, annular plaques that are persistent and resistant to topical therapies is most consistent with tinea corporis (dermatophytosis). Extensive dermatophytosis, especially when chronic and involving large areas of the body, should raise concern for underlying immunosuppression. HIV infection is a major risk factor for extensive, recurrent, or atypical fungal infections due to impaired cell-mediated immunity. Therefore, in addition to antifungal therapy, it is essential to perform HIV screening at this time. This helps identify an underlying cause of his susceptibility and allows timely initiation of appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antinuclear antibody assay: This test is used for diagnosing autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus or mixed connective tissue disease. These conditions may have skin manifestations, but they typically present with photosensitive rashes or systemic features, not annular, scaly plaques typical of dermatophytosis.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B serology: This is indicated in patients who are to receive systemic immunosuppressants such as methotrexate or biologics, since reactivation of hepatitis B can occur. However, it is not related to the evaluation of widespread tinea corporis and not indicated at this stage.

 

Option D. Rule out beta blocker usage: Beta blockers are associated with psoriasis exacerbation, not fungal infections. While psoriasis may present with plaques, they are usually sharply demarcated and silvery, not annular scaly lesions spreading in this fashion.

questions.text:
Match the following with the images:

 

 

  1. Lichen simplex chronicus

  2. Lichen scrofulosorum

  3. Lichen planus

  4. Lichen sclerosus

  5. Lichen nitidus
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-A, 2-D, 3-B, 4-C

 

1 - Lichen Simplex Chronicus (A): Lichen simplex chronicus results from chronic scratching or rubbing causing thick, leathery, hyperpigmented plaques with exaggerated skin markings. It is common on accessible sites like the ankle, wrist, or neck. Itching often triggers a vicious scratch-itch cycle worsened by stress or underlying skin conditions.

 

2 - Lichen Sclerosus (D): Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory disorder presenting as pale, atrophic, sclerotic plaques mainly involving the anogenital region. It leads to thinning, wrinkling, and sometimes scarring or architectural distortion of vulvar skin. Symptoms include intense pruritus and soreness, especially in women.

 

3 - Lichen Scrofulosorum (B): Lichen scrofulosorum is a tuberculid characterized by multiple grouped perifollicular papules mostly on trunk and limbs. It occurs as a hypersensitivity reaction to Mycobacterium tuberculosis elsewhere in the body, typically in young individuals. Lesions are asymptomatic or mildly pruritic and indicate latent or active TB.

 

4 - Lichen Planus (C): Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disorder presenting as violaceous, flat-topped, polygonal papules with fine white lines (Wickham striae). It mainly affects wrists, ankles, and mucous membranes. Pruritus is common and lesions may heal with post-inflammatory pigmentation; it involves an immune-mediated reaction often triggered by drugs or infections.

questions.text:
Match the following congenital lesions with the genetic defects:

 

 

A- NEMO

B-GNAQ

C- Collagen VII

D- Transglutaminase 1
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

1- C. Collagen VII: This gene defect causes dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, characterized by skin fragility and blister formation following minor trauma. The mutation affects anchoring fibrils in the dermo-epidermal junction. Clinically, it presents as congenital blistering and scarring primarily on hands, feet, and other trauma-prone areas.

 

2-D. Transglutaminase 1: Mutation in transglutaminase 1 causes lamellar ichthyosis, leading to thick, plate-like scaling and collodion membrane at birth. This enzyme is crucial for cross-linking proteins in the skin barrier. The child’s skin is dry, scaly, and prone to cracking due to impaired cornified envelope formation.

 

3-B. GNAQ: GNAQ mutations cause vascular malformations such as port-wine stains seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome. This gene encodes a G protein involved in signal transduction in endothelial cells. Patients present with cutaneous capillary malformations often associated with neurological and ocular abnormalities.

 

4-A. NEMO: NEMO gene mutations cause incontinentia pigmenti, an X-linked dominant disorder affecting skin, teeth, and the nervous system. The skin lesions progress through blistering, wart-like, hyperpigmented, and hypopigmented stages following Blaschko’s lines. It involves defective NF-kappaB pathway regulation critical for cell survival and immune response.

questions.text:
Match the histological images with the correct diagnosis:

 

 

  1. Pemphigus

  2. Hailey hailey

  3. Psoriasis

  4. Lichen planus

  5. Melanoma

  6. BCC

  7. Mycoises fungoides
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-A, 2-C, 3-D, 4-F

 

1-A: Pemphigus Vulgaris: Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized histologically by a suprabasal split in the epidermis. This means that the separation occurs just above the basal cell layer, leaving the basal cells attached to the basement membrane like a "row of tombstones." 

 

2-C: Psoriasis: Key findings: Uniform elongation of rete ridges, regular acanthosis, thinning of suprapapillary plates, and parakeratosis. Munro microabscesses (neutrophils in the stratum corneum) may be present, along with a chronic inflammatory background typical for psoriasis.

 

3-D: Lichen planus: Characterized by a dense, band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction, "saw-tooth" appearance of rete ridges, and hypergranulosis. Basal cell degeneration and Civatte bodies may also be seen in lichen planus. 

 

4-F: Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

  • This histopathological image shows nests of basaloid cells, a classic feature of Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC). 
  • In BCC, the tumor islands often display peripheral palisading, where cells at the edges align in a parallel fashion, resembling a picket fence.

questions.text:
Match the following images in the extremities with the diagnosis:

 

 

A-Diabetes

B-Graves disease

C-Lofgren syndrome

D-Varicose veins

E-Hypothyroidism

F-IBD
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-F

 

1-A: Diabetes (Diabetic ulcer): The first image shows a chronic, punched-out ulcer with an erythematous base and surrounding callus, typical of a diabetic ulcer. Diabetic ulcers occur due to neuropathy and vascular insufficiency, commonly on lower extremities. These ulcers are slow-healing and prone to infection, often seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes.

 

2-B: Graves disease (Pretibial myxedema): The second image shows bilateral, rubbery, non-pitting, waxy plaques on the shins, typical of pretibial myxedema. Associated with Graves disease, it is due to mucopolysaccharide deposition in the dermis. Lesions are usually non-tender, indurated, and may be skin-colored or erythematous.

 

3-C: Lofgren syndrome (Erythema nodosum): The third image demonstrates multiple, bright red, symmetric, tender nodules over the shins. This is classic for erythema nodosum, a hallmark of acute sarcoidosis in Lofgren syndrome. Lofgren syndrome also  features bilateral  hilar lymphadenopathy and arthritis.

 

4-F: IBD (Pyoderma gangrenosum): The fourth image shows a large, painful, necrotic ulcer with undermined violaceous edges. Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rapidly progressive ulcerative cutaneous condition seen in association with IBD. Lesions are extremely  painful, can  enlarge quickly, and heal with cribriform scarring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option D. Varicose veins: Leads to venous ulcers, typically around the medial malleolus, with irregular, shallow bases.

 

Option E. Hypothyroidism: Causes myxedema with generalized swelling, rarely produces specific localized leg lesions.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the OPD due to a skin condition. For the last 3 years, he has had small "pimples" on the posterior surface of her upper arms. The lesions are associated with mild pruritus during the winter months but are otherwise asymptomatic, and the patient is primarily concerned due to their appearance when he wears short-sleeved tops. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient's skin condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratosis pilaris

 

The most likely diagnosis is keratosis pilaris. Keratosis pilaris is characterized by multiple small, rough, follicular papules, commonly on the extensor surfaces of the upper arms, thighs, cheeks, or buttocks. The condition manifests as "chicken skin" with asymptomatic or mildly itchy lesions, which worsen in dry weather (especially winter). It is a benign, inherited disorder of keratinization, causing keratin plugs in hair follicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folliculitis: Typically presents with inflamed, erythematous, sometimes pustular lesions due to infection of hair follicles, often accompanied by pain or tenderness.

 

Option C. Miliaria: This is heat rash, showing tiny, clear vesicles or papules from sweat duct blockade, occurring in hot, humid conditions rather than the chronic follicular pattern here.

 

Option D. Pseudofolliculitis: Causes papules and pustules from ingrown hairs, often in shaving areas (beard, groin).

questions.text: A farmer presented to the outpatient department with a non-tender, non-mobile, non-compressible firm swelling over his palm as shown in the image. A few months back he got injured with a thorn. What is the presentation given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Implantation dermoid

 

The most likely diagnosis for this painless, firm, non-mobile swelling in the palm after a thorn injury is implantation dermoid. An implantation dermoid develops when epidermal or dermal cells are implanted into the subcutaneous tissues following trauma—such as a thorn prick—leading to a slowly growing cystic lesion. These cysts are most commonly seen in the hands, especially in people with a history of prior penetrating injury. The cyst is typically non-tender, firm, non-compressible, and not fixed to overlying skin or deeper tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ameloblastoma: Is a rare, typically benign tumor arising from odontogenic epithelium, primarily affecting the jawbone, especially the mandible near molars. It causes painless swelling and slow expansion of the jaw, sometimes leading to facial deformity, malocclusion, or tooth displacement.

 

Option B. Embryogenic dermoids: Are congenital cystic lesions arising from entrapment of ectodermal tissue during embryologic fusion. They are most commonly located along the midline structures of the head, face, or neck and appear shortly after birth or in early childhood

 

Option C. Sequestration dermoids: Develop congenitally from isolated islands of ectoderm during embryogenesis, often located on the scalp or in periorbital regions. These cysts contain skin adnexal structures and keratin debris.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of chronic acne. Over the last 6 months, the patient has tried several over-the-counter acne treatments without improvement. She has a history of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder and mild intellectual disability. Her mother has a seizure disorder, and her maternal grandmother died of kidney failure. Vital signs are within normal limits. Facial examination findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberous sclerosis

 

The most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition is tuberous sclerosis.

 

The image shows numerous red papules clustered on the nose and cheeks, consistent with facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum). In the clinical scenario, the patient has chronic treatment-resistant facial "acne," a history of mild intellectual disability, and a family history of seizures and renal disease—all classic for tuberous sclerosis complex. Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in TSC1 or TSC2, leading to hamartomas in multiple organs, including the skin (angiofibromas), brain (seizures, intellectual disability), and kidneys (angiomyolipomas, cysts, renal failure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fabry disease: Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by alpha-galactosidase A deficiency leading to globo-triaosyl-ceramide accumulation. It presents with angiokeratomas—small, dark red to black papules—typically involving the lower trunk, groin, and upper thighs. Systemic involvement includes neuropathic pain, kidney failure, and cardiac abnormalities.

 

Option B. Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1): NF1 is a genetic disorder characterized by café-au-lait macules, cutaneous and plexiform neurofibromas, axillary/inguinal freckling, and Lisch nodules of the iris. It does not cause acneiform or angiofibroma-like facial lesions. Learning disabilities and skeletal abnormalities can be associated.

 

Option D. Von Hippel-Lindau Disease: Von Hippel-Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant cancer syndrome with hemangioblastomas of the retina and central nervous system, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. It primarily presents with tumor-related symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the OPD due to skin lesions on his back. He first noted the spots 5 years ago and says they are becoming more numerous. The lesions are occasionally pruritic but are otherwise asymptomatic. Medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seborrehic keratosis

 

The likely diagnosis is A. Seborrheic keratosis. The image shows multiple, well-circumscribed, waxy, stuck-on, hyperpigmented papules and plaques, which are characteristic of seborrheic keratoses. Seborrheic keratoses are benign skin lesions that often appear in older adults and increase in number over time; they may be pruritic but are otherwise asymptomatic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actinic keratosis: presents as rough, scaly plaques on sun-exposed areas and is considered premalignant, not as "stuck-on" warty lesions.

 

 

Option C. Pityriasis versicolor: presents as hypo- or hyperpigmented patches with fine scale.

 

 

Option D. Acanthosis nigricans: shows velvety, hyperpigmented thickening of flexural surfaces, not discrete raised plaques

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a persistent skin rash. He has a 6-month history of a scaly rash involving the upper and lower extremities that is associated with mild pruritus. Medical history is notable for childhood asthma and orolabial herpes simplex virus infection. On examination, the patient has skin lesions as shown in the image below. This patient's disorder is most likely associated with which of the following extradermal complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deforming joint disease

 

This patient’s history and the image are classic for plaque psoriasis, an immune-mediated chronic skin disorder. The most significant extradermal (systemic) complication of psoriasis is psoriatic arthritis, which can lead to a deforming joint disease. Psoriasis is frequently associated with joint involvement: about 30% of patients will develop psoriatic arthritis, which can be deforming and disabling if untreated. The arthritis presents as joint pain, swelling, and can lead to permanent deformities, affecting fingers, toes (dactylitis), and the spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic glomerulonephritis: is not a typical complication of psoriasis . Although some studies show an increased risk of chronic kidney disease and glomerulonephritis in severe psoriasis, it is not a common or direct complication. The association often relates to comorbidities (e.g., diabetes, hypertension) or drug-related nephrotoxicity.

 

Option C. Medullary thyroid cancer: is linked to MEN syndromes, not psoriasis because this cancer arises from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid and is primarily linked with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) type 2 genetic mutations, which are associated with Mucosal Neuromas

 

Option D. Pulmonary fibrosis: is associated with other connective tissue and autoimmune diseases, not psoriasis because fibrotic lung disease principally occurs in systemic sclerosis, rheumatoid arthritis, and lupus rather than psoriasis. Psoriasis-related lung involvement is rare.

 

Systemic Manifestations of Psoriasis:

 

  1. Arthritis (Psoriatic arthritis, ~30%) – asymmetric oligoarthritis, DIP involvement, arthritis mutilans, axial disease.
  2. Nail changes – pitting, onycholysis, subungual hyperkeratosis, oil-drop sign.
  3. Ocular involvement – anterior uveitis, conjunctivitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca.
  4. Metabolic syndrome & cardiovascular risk – obesity, diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypertension, ↑ MI/stroke.
  5. Other organ associations – inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn’s), NAFLD, chronic kidney disease.
  6. Psychiatric manifestations – depression, anxiety, social withdrawal.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and yellowish discoloration of her skin. During this period, she has also had a 6 kg weight gain. She does not smoke and drinks one glass of wine daily. She follows a vegan diet that consists mainly of spinach, kale, and sweet potatoes. Physical examination shows yellowing of the skin. Her hands are cold to the touch and her nails appear brittle. Eye examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings is most likely in this patient's serum?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased beta-carotene concentration

 

This presentation is most consistent with carotenemia — excess dietary beta-carotene (from foods like spinach, kale, sweet potato) causing yellow-orange discoloration of the skin while sparing the sclera. The patient’s weight gain, cold hands, and brittle nails point to possible hypothyroidism, which can reduce conversion of carotene to vitamin A, worsening carotene accumulation. Carotenemia is benign and shows elevated serum beta-carotene without the laboratory pattern of hepatobiliary disease or hemolysis. Management is dietary modification and treating any underlying hypothyroidism if present. An image below shows Yellow orange discoloration of Carotenemia hand compared to subject reference on left side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased haptoglobin concentration: Low haptoglobin indicates intravascular hemolysis (hemoglobin released binds haptoglobin), seen with anemia, jaundice, dark urine, and often reticulocytosis. This patient lacks systemic hemolytic signs (no scleral icterus, no pallor described), so low haptoglobin is unlikely.

 

Option B. Increased alkaline phosphatase concentration: An elevated ALP suggests cholestasis or biliary obstruction (or bone disease). Those conditions commonly produce scleral icterus, pale stools, pruritus, and markedly abnormal liver panel .

 

Option C. Positive antimitochondrial antibodies: AMA positivity is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis, which causes progressive cholestasis in middle-aged women with pruritus, fatigue, and elevated ALP.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a painless growth in his mouth. Physical examination shows white patches on the oral mucosa along the gums that cannot be scraped off with gauze. The lesions have a granular texture. A combination HIV-1/2 immunoassay is negative. A biopsy of the lesion shows a marked increase in the thickness of the stratum corneum and the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in this layer. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral hairy leukoplakia

 

The most likely diagnosis is Oral hairy leukoplakia. Presents as white patches on the oral mucosa, especially on the lateral tongue or along the gums, which cannot be scraped off. Lesions often have a granular or corrugated (hairy) texture, typical for oral hairy leukoplakia. Histology shows marked hyperkeratosis with presence of nucleated keratinocytes (parakeratosis) in the upper epithelial layers. Typically caused by Epstein-Barr virus infection of oral mucosal cells. Common in immunocompromised patients but may rarely occur in immunocompetent individuals. Negative HIV test excludes oral candidiasis as a likely diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral candidiasis: White plaques are scrapeable and removable, revealing erythematous base. Also Oral candidiasis is commonly seen in Immunocompromised patients often who are HIV positive Histology shows fungal hyphae invading the superficial keratin layer.

 

Option B. Lichen Planus: Causes white, lacy (reticular) plaques or erosive lesions on oral mucosa, often painful. Histologically shows a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate with basal cell degeneration. Lesions are usually bilateral and symmetrical, unlike leukoplakia.

 

Option D. Diphtheria: Characterized by a thick gray pseudomembrane in the oropharynx or tonsils, causing sore throat and systemic symptoms. Histopathology reveals fibrinous exudate and necrotic debris, not keratinocyte proliferation or hyperkeratosis

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of multiple lesions on his chest and lower extremities. The lesions have progressively increased in size and are not painful or pruritic. Current medications include abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine. A photograph of the lesions is shown. A skin biopsy shows multiple spindle-shaped cells and lymphocytic infiltrate. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alpha-interferon

 

The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient’s lesion is alpha-interferon.

 

Diagnosis and Clinical Reasoning

 

This HIV-positive patient has multiple violaceous, non-tender, slowly progressive nodules and plaques, and skin biopsy demonstrates spindle-shaped cell proliferation with lymphocytic infiltrate—findings classic for Kaposi’s sarcoma. Kaposi’s sarcoma is a vascular tumor associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), especially common in immunocompromised individuals, and can be managed with antiretroviral therapy and, in certain cases, alpha-interferon for its antiviral and antiproliferative effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ganciclovir: An antiviral agent primarily used to treat CMV infections in immunocompromised patients. It is not effective in treating Kaposi's sarcoma as it lacks action against HHV-8 or tumor cells.

 

Option B. Nitazoxanide: An antiparasitic medication used for protozoal infections such as Cryptosporidium and Giardia.

 

Option D. Acyclovir: Used mainly against herpes simplex virus and varicella zoster virus; it does not show efficacy against HHV-8

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. She has multiple erythematous pustules and nodules over her face, for which she has received erythromycin and topical benzoyl peroxide. She is concerned that the therapy is ineffective. The physician recommends a drug on the condition that the patient agrees to use oral contraceptives. The molecular structure of the drug most likely recommended by the physician closely resembles a drug used to treat which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute promyelocytic leukaemia

 

This patient has severe nodulocystic acne that has not responded to erythromycin and topical benzoyl peroxide. The drug most likely recommended here is oral isotretinoin, a systemic retinoid that is highly effective for severe, treatment-resistant acne. Isotretinoin is a derivative of vitamin A and acts by decreasing sebaceous gland activity, reducing sebum production, and normalizing keratinization. Because of its teratogenic effects, strict contraception with oral contraceptive pills is required in women of childbearing potential. Structurally, isotretinoin resembles all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), the drug used in the management of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL, M3 AML). ATRA induces differentiation of immature promyelocytes, reversing the maturation arrest that characterizes APL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EGFR-positive non-small cell lung cancer: This condition is treated with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as erlotinib, gefitinib, and osimertinib. These agents block downstream signaling pathways that drive proliferation and survival of malignant lung cells.

 

Option C. BRAF-positive metastatic melanoma: BRAF V600E mutation–positive melanomas are treated with targeted therapy using BRAF inhibitors (eg, vemurafenib, dabrafenib), often combined with MEK inhibitors (trametinib). These agents inhibit the MAPK/ERK pathway to suppress uncontrolled cell growth. They are kinase inhibitors and have no similarity in structure or mechanism to retinoids.

 

Option D. HER2-positive gastric cancer: This is managed with trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody that targets HER2/neu receptors, blocking proliferative signaling and mediating antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of severe itching in the area of her genitals. She reports that the itching is most severe at night. Her current sexual partner is experiencing similar symptoms. Pelvic examination shows vulvar excoriations. A photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phthirus pubis

 

This patient presents with intense nocturnal genital pruritus and vulvar excoriations, along with her partner having similar symptoms. The photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair shows Phthirus pubis (crab louse) attached to the hair shaft. These lice are transmitted mainly via sexual contact and cause irritation due to hypersensitivity reactions to louse saliva. Clinical findings include erythematous papules, excoriations, and sometimes visible lice or nits on pubic hair. Treatment involves topical pediculicides such as permethrin or malathion, along with partner treatment and linen decontamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pediculus humanus: This species includes Pediculus humanus capitis (head louse) and Pediculus humanus corporis (body louse). Head lice infest the scalp, causing pruritus, while body lice are vectors for diseases such as epidemic typhus and trench fever. They are not typically restricted to the genital area.

 

Option C. Epidermophyton floccosum: A dermatophyte fungus that causes superficial skin infections like tinea cruris (jock itch), tinea pedis, and tinea corporis. It presents as well-demarcated, scaly, erythematous lesions, not nocturnal itching with parasites attached to hair shafts.

 

Option D. Sarcoptes scabiei: This mite causes scabies, which presents with intense nocturnal itching, burrows, and papular eruptions in interdigital webs, wrists, axillae, and genitalia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old HIV-positive male presents with lesions on his skin as shown below, along with signs of hepatosplenomegaly. His CD4 count is critically low. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bartonella henselae

 

The most likely organism responsible for these lesions  presenting as multiple red-purple nodules or papules, often with systemic involvement such as hepatosplenomegaly in an HIV-positive patient with low CD4 and hepatosplenomegaly is Bartonella henselae (bacillary angiomatosis).

 

Bacillary angiomatosis in HIV patients is caused by Bartonella henselae (and rarely by B. quintana), Lesions can mimic Kaposi sarcoma but are associated with neutrophilic infiltrates and a positive Warthin–Starry stain for bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartonella bacilliformis: Causes Oroya fever and Peruvian wart, but not typical in HIV or as bacillary angiomatosis.

 

Option B. HTLV: HTLV is a retrovirus associated with adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma and HTLV-associated myelopathy.

 

Option D. HHV-8: Associated with Kaposi’s sarcoma (can mimic), but lesions are violaceous macules, plaques, or nodules resulting from proliferation of endothelial cells infected with HHV-8.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with a great toe infection. She had a significant discoloration with a subungual hyperkeratosis that caused surface changes. She was suspected of having onychomycosis. Which is the topical drug given in toenail onychomycosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tavaborole

 

Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nails, commonly caused by dermatophytes (e.g., Trichophyton rubrum), and presents with nail discoloration, subungual hyperkeratosis, and nail plate deformity. Tavaborole is a topical antifungal agent (oxaborole class) that inhibits fungal protein synthesis by blocking leucyl-tRNA synthetase. It is FDA-approved for topical treatment of toenail onychomycosis and is applied daily for 48 weeks. Tavaborole is particularly useful for mild to moderate cases or when systemic therapy is contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole: An oral triazole antifungal used in the treatment of systemic mycoses and onychomycosis. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis. Oral itraconazole is effective for toenail disease and is used in pulse or continuous regimens.

 

Option C. Griseofulvin: An older oral antifungal that inhibits fungal mitosis by disrupting microtubule function. It was historically used for dermatophyte infections of skin, hair, and nails but is now largely replaced by terbinafine and itraconazole due to lower efficacy and longer treatment duration. Not given topically for nails.

 

Option D. Caspofungin: An echinocandin antifungal that inhibits β-glucan synthesis in the fungal cell wall. It is used intravenously for serious systemic infections such as invasive candidiasis and aspergillosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents with multiple blistering skin lesions. A skin biopsy reveals acantholysis, characterized by the loss of adhesion between keratinocytes. Which of the following conditions is least likely to display acantholytic cells on histological examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection

 

  • Acantholysis refers to the separation and loss of adhesion between keratinocytes within the epidermis, leading to the formation of distinct "acantholytic cells." This histological feature is a hallmark of several dermatological conditions. 
  • In the context of the presented case, the presence of acantholysis suggests a disorder that disrupts keratinocyte connections. 
  • Pemphigus, herpes simplex infection, and bullous impetigo are all associated with such disruptions, resulting in acantholytic cells. 
  • However, Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is characterized by a different cytopathic effect known as koilocytic change. 
  • This involves perinuclear halos and nuclear atypia in keratinocytes, which are distinct from the acantholytic changes observed in other conditions. 
  • Therefore, HPV infection does not typically exhibit acantholysis and is least likely to present with acantholytic cells on histological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus: Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder where autoantibodies target Desmogleins, components of desmosomes that facilitate keratinocyte adhesion. This disruption leads to prominent acantholysis and intraepidermal blister formation.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex infection: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection causes ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes, leading to vesicle formation accompanied by acantholysis. Histology may also reveal multinucleated giant cells and viral inclusions.

 

Option D. Bullous impetigo: Bullous impetigo, often caused by Staphylococcus aureus producing exfoliative toxins, leads to the cleavage within the epidermis and acantholysis, resulting in blister formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acantholysis, the loss of keratinocyte adhesion, is observed in conditions such as pemphigus, herpes simplex infection, and bullous impetigo, but not typically in Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, which instead causes koilocytic changes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the triad of poikiloderma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skin hypertrophy

 

Poikiloderma is a chronic skin condition characterized by a triad of features: skin atrophy, pigmentary changes (hyper- or hypopigmentation), and telangiectasia. These changes usually result from chronic sun exposure, genetic disorders, or certain connective tissue diseases. Skin hypertrophy, which is thickening of the skin, is not a component of poikiloderma; instead, the skin becomes thin and fragile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pigmentary changes: These include hyperpigmented or hypopigmented patches due to melanocyte dysfunction or chronic photodamage. 

 

Option C. Telangiectasia: Small, dilated blood vessels appear on the surface of the skin, often visible as fine red lines. Telangiectasias contribute to the mottled appearance typical of poikiloderma.

 

Option D. Skin atrophy: The affected skin is thin, fragile, and often wrinkled, making it more susceptible to trauma

questions.text:
Match the following nail appearances: 

 

  1. Arsenic poisoning
  2. Lymphedema
  3. Renal failure 
  4. Malnourishment 

 

a) Muerhke’s lines

b) Mees lines

c) Yellow nail

d) Leukonychia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

1. Arsenic poisoning → Mees lines (b): Transverse white lines across the nail plate that move with nail growth, typically appearing after arsenic or other heavy metal exposure. They indicate acute systemic insult.

 

2. Lymphedema → Yellow nails (c): Nails appear thickened, slow-growing, and yellow due to lymphatic stasis. Often associated with chronic lymphedema, impaired nail growth, and secondary infections.

 

3. Renal failure → Leukonychia (d): Diffuse whitening of the nail plate, sometimes with ground-glass appearance, caused by protein abnormalities and metabolic changes seen in chronic renal disease.

 

4. Malnourishment → Muehrcke’s lines (a): Paired transverse white bands that do not move with nail growth, representing hypoalbuminemia, commonly observed in protein-calorie malnutrition or liver disease.

questions.text: A 4-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents for a well-child check. She was evaluated 2 weeks ago for a rash in the diaper area. At that visit, the patient was found to have erythematous papules in the diaper area that spared the skin folds. Her symptoms improved with use of a petrolatum barrier ointment with every diaper change. Today, vital signs and physical examination are normal. Which of the following most likely contributed to this patient's prior skin findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered local skin pH

 

This infant had erythematous papules in the diaper area that spared skin folds, which improved with petrolatum barrier ointment—classic features of irritant diaper dermatitis. The main contributing factor is prolonged exposure to urine and feces, which raises the local skin pH, disrupting the acidic skin barrier and making the epidermis more susceptible to irritation. The elevated pH activates fecal enzymes (lipases and proteases) that break down the stratum corneum, leading to inflammation and erythema. Management includes frequent diaper changes, barrier creams, and maintaining proper hygiene to restore skin pH and prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormal keratin expression: Disorders like ichthyosis or keratinopathic epidermal disorders involve defective keratin production, causing scaling and barrier defects. These are genetic and chronic, rather than acute, and usually present with diffuse scaling.

 

Option C. Increased hapten sensitization: This occurs in allergic contact dermatitis, where small molecules (haptens) trigger an immune response. Allergic rashes often involve skin folds, have vesicles, and may recur with repeated exposure to the allergen.

 

Option D. Local bacterial colonization: Bacterial overgrowth (eg, Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus) can exacerbate diaper dermatitis, causing pustules or oozing. However, simple irritant diaper rash is primarily non-infectious, and secondary infection occurs only if the barrier is broken or the inflammation persists.

questions.text: Identify the lines shown below
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kraissl lines

 

The lines shown are Kraissl lines, demonstrated in living individuals, which correspond to natural wrinkle lines of the face and are oriented perpendicular to the action of underlying facial muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Skin tension lines: General term that includes Langer's lines, Kraissl lines, and relaxed skin tension lines—these define directions for optimal healing after incisions but are not specific anatomical patterns.

 

Option C. Blaschko lines: Represent embryological migration patterns of skin cells, often seen in genetic or mosaic skin disorders, and appear as whorled, S-shaped, or linear patterns not following wrinkles.

 

 

Option D. Langer lines: Describe lines of maximal skin tension based on collagen orientation, typically determined in cadavers, and differ substantially from natural wrinkle or expression lines, especially on the face.
